Grindr is for safe, authentic connection.

Adults only (i.e., at least 18, or older in certain jurisdictions).

Be yourself (donât pretend to be someone else).

In private (chats and Albums): You can post nudes of yourself (no images of others without their explicit and enthusiastic consent). Donât post content that is violent or trying to promote or sell anything.

Introduction

At Grindr, we believe in a world where all LGBTQ people can live and love with pride. Our Community Guidelines are written and enforced to support these values:

Kindness, inclusion, belonging, and care for each other.

Safety, authenticity, and the right to privacy.

Sex positivity, consent, health, and well-being.

These guidelines are written to help you understand how you should behave, what is expected of you, and how to help make Grindr a welcoming and fun community.

We believe in educating our community and giving them the chance to correct their behavior, so in certain situations, we may issue warnings, proactively block certain discriminatory or hurtful words from being used on profiles, or remove content as a first response. However, in the case of severe violations or repeated offenses, we take more serious measures, such as permanent bans. To ensure fair outcomes, we have a robust appeal process, and we take pride in our careful and thorough moderation practices.Â

ðï¸ For more info, read How Grindr moderates content and profiles.

If you have a negative experience, please know that we care about you and your experience, and that help is available. Please take care of yourself and think about what you need in order to heal. Know that you can report any incidents to Grindr, and that your reports are handled with discretion. Consider reaching out to these LGBTQ friendly helplines across 16 countries and chat resources.

And, so you know, you can use our built-in safeguards to better control your own experience on Grindr by muting conversations and blocking profiles. If youâre not sure whether someone else is breaking our community guidelines or not, feel free to reach out to us to ask. Weâre here to help.

â

Safety, authenticity, and the right to privacy

Â Â Â Â Â 1. You must be an adult to use Grindr.

This means you must be at least 18 or older in some countries. We encourage you to report profiles that you suspect are underage and profiles you suspect may be engaging in the exploitation of minors.

We take this age limit very seriously, and suspected underage accounts are banned immediately.

Pretending to be a minor (for any reason) will result in a permanent ban.

Our policy on minor activity extends to communication: if someone on Grindr knowingly communicates with a minor or someone that they believe to be a minor, that is also a violation of our age policy.

We do not allow any images of minors, in any context. This includes images where a minorâs face is blurred out or is in the background.Â

Finally, we have a zero-tolerance policy for the sharing or posting of child sexual abuse material. Any images or depictions of minors in a sexual context are strictly prohibited.

Help keep our community safe: If you see a profile, chat message, or any other content that indicates a user is a minorâor see any images or videos depicting a minorâplease immediately report that to us here or by tapping the Ã icon in the upper-right corner of the screen â Report â Underage.Â

We report instances potentially related to child endangerment to the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children. Grindr is a member of the WeProtect Global Alliance and the Technology Coalition. Additionally, we use proactive methods to detect potentially harmful or illegal content regarding minors.

Â Â Â Â Â 2. Grindr is for genuine connections, not buying or selling.

We appreciate a good side-hustle, and itâs cool to invite people to an event or share resources or information, but Grindr is for personal use only. You canât use Grindr to buy or sell anything, to advertise or represent a business or organization, or to ask for money or other goods or services.Â

This includes:

Asking for money, gifts, or donations; giving out payment app or bank account info.

Offers to buy any kind of good or service, or using Grindr to find people to sell you something.

Advertising or sending of promotional materials for a business, club, event, contest, or organization.

Sugar daddy/baby arrangements, "gen"/ generous, âpay to playâ or p2p, findom, paid massages, escorting services.

Emojis commonly associated with buying/ selling goods or services.

ðï¸ Read more on our Commercial activity & solicitation help page.

Health organizations and nonprofits looking to conduct outreach should contact Grindr For Equality (G4E) for support here. We have limited opportunities for official advertising/ collaboration with organizations. Unofficial outreach through business profiles, or spamming users with links or requests to donate is not allowed and may result in a ban.

Â Â Â Â Â 3. Be yourself.

We offer you the freedom to choose what you share about yourself, but the information you share should be authentic and true. We donât allow scamming, fake accounts, or the use of Grindr to entrap our users. We work with NGOs to help challenge entrapments and honeytraps of users in high risk contexts.

We provide the option of having a discreet profile which doesnât have to reveal a real identity. However, you are still bound by these Community Guidelines and cannot impersonate anyone else.

Images must be of you, or created by you (and not represent anyone else).

If your profile is reported as being fake (or a âcatfishâ), we may ask you to verify your identity using secure methods to keep your profile active.

Respect othersâ intellectual property rights, and donât post copyrighted images from others, images of other people without their explicit consent, or deepfakes/ AI generated images/ synthetic media.

ðï¸ Read our Scam Awareness Guide to educate yourself on the types of scams out there.

Â Â Â Â Â 4. Protect privacy and personal information.

In the interest of safety and protecting privacy, we ask that you donât publicly post private information (yours or othersâ).Â Â

All profile information provided on Grindr is completely optional and can be deleted or edited at any time. That said, filling out your profile with some information about who you are and what youâre looking for may lead to more successful matches.

We ask that you donât post the following on your public profile:

Phone numbers, email addresses, physical addresses, or links to (or your username on) private communication apps like WhatsApp.

Financial information like bank account numbers, or links to (or your username on) financial apps like Venmo, Cash App, or Zelle.

You may not share other peopleâs information, for any reason (even if you mean well). This includes sharing private chats or images, publicly outing someone, or linking their real-world identity (including social media accounts, real names, etc.) to a Grindr profile.

You may post your own social media profiles (such as Instagram, TikTok).

Do not share the password to your Grindr account with others. We will not ever ask for your password, though we may help you change it if you forget it.

ðï¸ Read our Privacy Policy and Privacy Center for more info.

â

Kindness, inclusion, belonging, and care for each other.

Â Â Â Â Â 1. Treat others well, and share your desires in a positive, affirmative way.

Grindr is a place where people come to have fun, feel good about themselves, and get to know each other. We believe in free expression, but not at the expense of other people. Being kind and making others feel good about themselves will make you feel good too.

Harassment and bullying are unacceptable on Grindr. Even small statements can ruin someoneâs day. Remember the old adage: âif you canât say something nice, donât say anything at all.â You donât need to hurt other people to make yourself feel better.Â

You can really harm other people by rejecting them based just on their identity. This is specifically harmful for people from historically marginalized backgrounds.

By treating groups of people as though theyâre all the same, you donât get to know them for who they truly are. People are unique, and we ask that you treat them that way.

We donât allow hate or discrimination. This includes use of harmful stereotypes; dehumanization and discrimination; bigotry motivated by hatred, prejudice or intolerance; and violence, threats, and abuse of all kinds. It applies to profiles, chats, and in-person behavior. Please report it when you see or experience it.

This is why we ask that you share your desires in a positive way, rather than saying who you donât want to see. For example:

Interested in gay men

Looking for my bi+ babes

POC to the front

T4T

Hit me up if youâre femme!

Power dynamics are often in play, and some groups are historically marginalized and more likely to be discriminated against. Although some people may enjoy power play or fetishization as part of a sexual kink, it's important to always ensure consent, and be aware of your own power dynamics to avoid causing harm. We are particularly committed to combating abuse which contributes to more marginalization and discrimination. We donât allow:

Racism, including sexual racism, statements which target and discriminate against marginalized groups and identities (such as â[this group] onlyâ or âno one from [marginalized group]â), and other known racist signals.

Fetishization, which dehumanizes someone at the expense of another personâs desire by oversexualizing based on a single trait, characteristic, identity, or type (such as by race or gender).

Transphobia, targeted and malicious deadnaming, misgendering, and discrimination based on gender, gender identity, and gender stereotypes. Trans and nonbinary people are welcome on Grindr.

Discrimination based on marginalized identities, such as country of origin, sexual orientation (such as biphobia, homophobia, and aphobia), health status (such as HIV status, mental health status), gender (such as misogyny), religious affiliation, disability or neurodivergence.

Shaming, bullying, harassment, or repeated toxic behavior. This includes body shaming or bullying based on physical characteristics (such as body type, weight, hair or skin color).

Hate groups, including promotion of or affiliation with hateful and violent organizations or their activities (including terrorist organizations and violent extremist groups).

Promoting or advertising harmful so-called "conversion therapy" or related programs that attempt to change a personâs sexual orientation or gender identity.

If you feel safe doing so, stand up for others. When you encounter negative content or behavior, in addition to reporting, you may want to stand up for others as a bystander. If you do want to say something, we recommend keeping comments short and simple. Here are some scripts to try:

Thatâs not okay.

That word comes from a racist stereotype and is hurtful.Â

I find it really disrespectful that you said that.

Rejection can be hard. We've all been there, and it hurts. Of course, not everyone will be into you. That's just life, but it doesn't make it hurt less!

If someone does tell you no politely, it's best to just move on. If someone rejects you harshly, please Report/Block them and move on. Responding in kind won't help anything. We do not ban people for (politely!) rejecting others. You can always use your profile to let others know how you like to be told no.

If you want to tell someone youâre not interested, let them down gently but firmly. We recommend keeping things general â no need to insult people in the process. Below are some scripts to try:

Hey, sorry, donât think itâs a match for me. Good luck :)

Not a match â wishing you the best!

Iâm flattered, but I donât think weâre a match. Best of luck!

ðï¸ We have lots of resources on this topic, including:

See our Kindr Grindr campaign.

Read about Combating racism.

Watch a video on sexual racism.

Read our Gender Identity FAQs and resources.

Watch videos on transphobia and femme shaming.

Watch videos on body shaming and HIV status.

Â Â Â Â Â 2. No violence, in any form.

In a world that is not always accepting of LGBTQ people, itâs important to us to make sure that Grindr is a safe space.Â

We do not allow:

Violent behavior, either online or offline. This includes assault, robbery, stalking, and other serious in-person behavior.Â

Threats. Credible threats may be escalated to law enforcement in contexts where it is safe to do so.Â

Offensive or harmful content, even if there was no ill intent; memes or jokes that are disparaging or discriminatory of others; animal abuse imagery, etc.

Encouraging dangerous behavior, such as self harm, dangerous challenges and pranks.

The use of Grindr to entrap or coerce our users for any reason.

Grindr is based in the United States of America and, regardless of where you live, donât do anything on Grindr that is illegal according to the laws in California or the United States.

ðï¸ Read our Safety Tips and Holistic Security Guide to make informed decisions about your safety.

Â Â Â Â Â 3. Uphold civic, democratic, and community integrity.Â

Democracy and civic participation is key to ensuring that the LGBTQ community has equal rights, and we periodically encourage our community to vote.

We allow (and encourage!) our community to express their political opinions and encourage others to vote, talk about who they are voting for, exchange information on the democratic process, etc.

We donât allow manipulation, harassment, intimidation, spreading disinformation, or interference of the democratic process.

We expect people to be respectful of each otherâs differences of opinion.

Our policy on hate speech still applies even during political discussions.

Â Â Â Â Â 4. We will treat you with care and respect, and expect the same in return.

Weâre human and hard-working. Weâre here to make your experience on Grindr great, and we expect you to interact with us in good faith.Â

Our rules on civil behavior extend to interactions with our staff. Please donât harass us or threaten us. Complaints and issues should be brought up here and not through unofficial channels.Â

Misuse of our reporting system is not allowed. This includes sending us multiple reports for the same issue, maliciously reporting people, or reporting someone simply because of their identity.Â

â

Health, well-being, sex positivity, and consent.

Â Â Â Â Â 1. Support the health and well-being of others.Â

ðï¸ We care deeply about the well-being of our users. Grindr for Equality and our Community team provide education on sexual health, pandemics and outbreaks like Covid and Mpox, racism, gender and sexuality, safety, holistic security, and privacy and more to keep the community informed.

In an effort to discourage harmful practices, we do not allow profiles centered around or mainly consisting of drug content.Â

We donât allow:

Demonstrating or encouraging irresponsible drug use.

Public mention of non-prescription drugs (other than cannabis) unless in the context of addiction recovery.

Profiles that are centered around or mainly consisting of drug content (including cannabis).

Discussing or participating in the buying or selling of drugs (of any kind).

ðï¸ Read this resource page for help with addiction.

We donât allow Disinformation. We work with trusted medical experts when sharing information about vaccines, outbreaks, and health information.

For the safety of our community, depictions of self harm or expressing suicidal thoughts can be harmful, so we may remove this content from public profiles.

If you feel you or someone else is in immediate danger or need emergency assistance, please call emergency services in your area if you feel that is safe for you, or reach out to one of these LGBTQ friendly organizations who can provide support to those experiencing emotional distress.

Â Â Â Â Â 2. Consent is essential. Respect boundaries, and state your own.

Grindr is a sex-positive place, and we want everyone to have fun without being hurt. The key to this is consent: a discussion between you and others about what you want to do together and what your boundaries are.

Ensuring consent means getting explicit and enthusiastic confirmation that your partner/s feels safe, affirmed, and are enjoying themselves.

Providing consent means letting your partner/s know that you are enjoying yourself and feel comfortable with everything that is happening.

Consent is always reversible â you can change your mind about what you want to do at any time, including stopping everything. Just because you may have given consent for something on the Grindr app, over text, or in person, does not mean you are obligated to do that when you meet up.

Here are some specifics about consent on Grindr:

Not everyone on Grindr wants to have an explicit conversation right away (or, in some cases, ever). Ask for consent before sending nude photos or explicit messages, and donât post these things publicly. We donât allow pornography or sexually explicit content in public profiles.

Only post and share images of you. If you want to share an image that includes other people, get their explicit and enthusiastic consent and permission first.

If someone shares your images without permission, or threatens to do so, let us know. We donât allow the sharing of non-consensual imagery. This includes situations where someone has shared images off Grindr, or is threatening to do so.

If youâre going to meet someone in person, itâs essential to ensure consent before any sexual activity. We take reports of sexual assault extremely seriously, and will ban for in-person/ offline behavior.

ðï¸ Read more about consent.

We believe in informed consent around sexual health.

To better support the communityâs well-being, and at the recommendation of health experts and the Grindr community, weâve added the option to share your self-reported health information with other people on Grindr.

One of the most important things you can do if you get diagnosed with an STI is to tell your partners. That way, they can make an informed decision and get tested too.

If you knowingly put someone at risk of an infection and donât disclose it, this puts their health at risk. This violates our harmful offline behavior policy.

ðï¸ Read more about what health information you can choose to add to your profile, and about your Health information Privacy.

Image and media guidelines

Grindr is a place for people of all shapes, sizes, ethnicities, genders, and identities to express themselves and their sexuality joyfully and freely.

That said, in order to keep a healthy and thriving community, there are certain types of images that we cannot allow (images include photos and videos). We have different rules for public and private content.

In public (profiles): images must be of you, and canât be pornographic, violent, or illegal.

In private (chats and Albums): you can post nudity, but still no violent or illegal content.

THE DETAILS:

Keep nudes private. Grindr is a sex-positive place, but not everyone on Grindr wants to have an explicit conversation right away (or, in some cases, ever). Ask for consent before sending nude photos or explicit messages, and donât post these things publicly.

On profiles, we allow underwear photos, non-pornographic sexual poses, and some images of butts if they are non-graphic and without an overly sexual context. Our user experience has to be acceptable to Apple and Googleâs app store decision-makers, lest we get kicked off their platforms.Â

Sexually explicit images are not allowed on profile photos:

Images depicting pornographic sex acts, real or mimicked, clothed or unclothed, alone or with others.

Filters/ scribbles used to mask pornographic content. (If you can still tell that itâs pornography, itâs not allowed).

Sexually explicit nudity, such as exposed genitals.

We are working towards gender-inclusive photo rules. Unfortunately due to current app store policies, we must categorize womenâs nipples as prohibited nudity. Men and nonbinary people are allowed to show their nipples. For our rules that are not about nudity, all people are treated equally.

Bodily fluids, including semen, urine, or blood (fake blood in costumes is ok).

We ask that you keep Grindr joyful and positive. This means no content anywhere (including albums and chats) that is violent, offensive, illegal, or spammy.

Images must be of you or created by you. Sharing images of your partner(s) or of anyone else must only be done with affirmative, enthusiastic consent.

We do allow creative content (doesnât have to show you or your face) including photos or drawings youâve made yourself.

To be specific, we donât allow the following anywhere on Grindr:

Images that arenât of you

Any images of people without their consent.

Images of minors in any context, even if theyâre in the background or blurred.

Child sexual abuse material.Â

Images that are copyrighted by someone else, have watermarks, or that we believe to not be of you or taken by you.

Images should tell us something about you, or express yourself somehow. We will remove confusing and/or low quality âjunkâ images (like solid black boxes, scribbles, etc.)

Images of celebrities or public figures of any kind (actors, musicians, politicians, etc.) unless itâs actually you (in which case: welcome!). This includes images of celebrity impersonators where it could be unclear if the person is an impersonator or the actual celebrity.

Deepfakes, synthetic, or AI-generated images passed off as being you (digital illustrations based on real images of yourself are fine).

Violent or disturbing images

Weapons and firearms (images that are clearly of toys and are in a non-threatening context are ok).

Blood or gore (images of costumes with fake blood are ok); animal torture; severely injured or mutilated animals.

Images that are violent or threatening against any person or group, including public and/or political figures (including cartoons or illustrations).

Content that can be found to be hurtful and insensitive (including jokes or memes), or show affiliation with or support of violent, hateful, or extremist groups.

Images or descriptions of self harm or suicide.

Drug use

Images of drugs (including implied drug use & drug paraphernalia). Casual references to cannabis, tobacco, and alcohol are allowed (for example, a cannabis leaf on a t-shirt; an image of someone smoking), but we do not allow images that are solely or mainly focused on substances or that we believe may be meant to advertise drugs or promote drug use.

Commercial activity

Images that are advertising items or services for sale, focusing mainly on a product logo or brand, or featuring website addresses for a particular company.

Images depicting or focused on cash, credit cards, etc.

A note on moderation:

We use both automated and human review to moderate images, and are working to reduce bias through AI learning and team education. If you see content on Grindr that violates any of our guidelines, please let us know here or within the app by tapping the Ã icon in the upper-right corner of the screen then tapping Report.

We do not take gender (with the exception of nipples, see above statements on app store restrictions), ethnicity, age, body hair, or body type (or body hair type) into consideration when deciding whether to approve a photo.

Panimula

Sa Grindr, naniniwala kami sa mundo kung saan maaaring mabuhay at magmahal ang mga taong LGBTQ nang walang itinatago. Isinulat at ipinapatupad ang aming Mga Alituntunin ng Komunidad para suportahan ang mga pagpapahalagang ito:

Kabaitan, pagsasama, pakikibahagi, at pagmamalasakit sa isaât isa.

Kaligtasan, pagiging tunay, at karapatan sa pagkapribado.

Pagiging positibo tungkol sa usapang pagtatalik, pahintulot, kalusugan, at kapakanan.

Isinulat ang mga alituntuning ito para matulungan kang maunawaan kung paano ka dapat kumilos, ano ang inaasahan sa iyo, at paano makakatulong na gawing bukas at masayang komunidad ang Grindr.

Naniniwala kami sa pagtuturo sa aming komunidad at sa pagbibigay sa kanila ng pagkakataong itama ang kanilang pag-uugali, kaya sa ilang partikular na sitwasyon, posibleng magbigay kami ng mga babala, maagap na mag-block ng ilang partikular na salitang may diskriminasyon o mapanakit para hindi magamit ang mga ito sa mga profile, o mag-alis ng content bilang unang tugon. Gayunpaman, sa mga sitwasyon ng malubha o paulit-ulit na paglabag, mas seryoso ang gagawin naming hakbang, gaya ng mga permanenteng pagbabawal. Para masiguro ang mga patas na kalalabasan, mayroon kaming maayos na proseso ng pag-apela, at ipinagmamalaki namin ang aming mga maingat at mabusising pamamaraan ng pangangasiwa.

ðï¸ Para sa higit pang impormasyon, basahin kung Paano pinapangasiwaan ng Grindr ang content at mga profile.

Kung nagkaroon ka ng negatibong karanasan, dapat mong malamang pinapahalagahan ka namin at ang karanasan mo, at makakahingi ka ng tulong. Pakialagaan ang iyong sarili at pag-isipan kung ano ang kailangan mo para maghilom. Alam mong pwede kang mag-ulat ng anumang insidente sa Grindr, at pinapangasiwaan ang mga ulat mo nang may pag-iingat. Isaalang-alang na makipag-ugnayan sa mga helpline na ito na para sa LGBTQ sa 16 na bansa at mga resource na chat.

At, para malaman mo, pwede mong gamitin ang aming mga built-in na safeguard para mas makontrol ang karanasan mo sa Grindr sa pamamagitan ng pag-mute sa mga pag-uusap at pag-block sa mga profile. Kung hindi ka sigurado kung nilalabag ba o hindi ng isang tao ang aming mga alituntunin ng komunidad, huwag mag-atubiling makipag-ugnayan sa amin para magtanong. Nandito kami para tumulong.

Kaligtasan, pagiging tunay, at karapatan sa pagkapribado

1. Dapat ay nasa hustong gulang ka para magamit ang Grindr.

Ibig sabihin nito, dapat ay 18 taong gulang ka pataas o mas matanda pa sa ilang bansa. Hinihikayat ka naming mag-ulat ng mga profile na pinaghihinalaan mong menor de edad at sangkot sa pagsasamantala sa mga menor de edad.

Lubos naming sineseryoso ang limitasyong ito sa edad, at kaagad na pagbabawalan ang mga account na pinaghihinalaang menor de edad.
